predicate.note: Frames file for 'frustrate' based on sentences in wsj. Verbnet entry 31.1 (verbs of emotion) but there seems to be a difference between this verb and others of that class (see note at end).

roleset.name: cause angst

example.name: would this actually work?
example.text: Sometimes, if the hacker seemed to be into a sensitive file, he would drag his keychain across the terminal *trace* to create static or slow the system down *trace* to frustrate his quarry.

example.name: passive
example.text: Corporate leaders, frustrated *trace* by double-digit increases in health-care costs, are beginning to sound like liberal Democrats.

example.name: exceptional use of arg2
example.text: But the Fed isn't enthusiastic about Treasury efforts to bring down the value of the dollar through intervention in foreign-exchange markets, and the Treasury is frustrated *trace* at the Fed's reluctance to cut interest rates to pull down the dollar's value.
example.arg: the Fed's reluctance to cut interest rates to pull down the dollar's value

roleset.note: Usually for class 31.1 arg2 is the instrument, and only present when the subject is also present. This is exceptional. It would seem weird to introduce arg0 by 'at', and there's a real semantic difference between the causer of frustration, and the target. of the frustration.
